bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to E.J. Scannell, July 5, 1923

div1.p: Carter thanks Scannell for his critique of Carter's epidemiology paper and states that Scannell will find well-educated physicians in Brazil.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to E.J. Scannell, July 5, 1923
div1.opener:
Book
Scannel
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
July 5, 1923.
Dear Doctor Scannell:
div1.p:
When I saw the Boston postmark with your handwriting under it I said:
“He is going to Brazil with White.”

The reason I mentioned writing Sunday was to explain the delay in
answering your letter. I do all my private correspondence Sunday.

So far from an apology for writing your first letter, you ought to
be the recipient of thanks therefor. I want to get as much criticism on the
Epidemiology as I can. Several field men have written to me about it
already. Your criticism was distinctly constructive. The factor of low-
ered temperature preventing the development of the parasite in the in-
sect has--as I said--analogy with malaria and is a thing to be consid-
ered. I will be able to incorporate some of the ideas I get from other
people in the paper as published. It is very well to get different
points of view upon the same thing.

You will find a pretty well educated lot of men among the physi-
cians in Brazil and not a few of them men of force and initiative as
well. In my judgment, Brazil is far ahead of any part of Spanish Amer-
ica that I have seen. If you see a Dr. Mulher: or Torres: or Cerqueira
in Bahia--to any of the three remember me most kindly. The first was
Health Officer when I was there and you may tell him I strongly recom-
mended at that time the I. H. B. making an allotment to assist Bahia in
its Stegomyia work. The War, however, made everything fall through.
With very best wishes, in which Laura, who is writing this, joings
